oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Hanmore Family Farm, Newburgh, NY
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:description:
This photograph depicts the family home and farm of Dr. Louis E. Hanmore. The compound consists of three wooden buildings. Three family members sit on a fence in front of one of the buildings.

Dr. Louis. E. Hanmore (May 29, 1859-September 19, 1905) was a medical doctor born and raised in Newburgh, NY. He graduated from Newburgh Free Academy in 1876. He went on to study pharmacology and medicine. He graduated from the College and Physicians and Surgeons in New York City in 1884. He returned in Newburgh where he set up his practice.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Steamboat Robert Fulton at Day Line Dock, Hudson-Fulton Celebration
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: G. E. Howard
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This photograph depicts the Day Line Steamboat Robert Fulton docking at the Newburgh Landing during the Hudson-Fulton Celebration. Steamboats enabled individuals to travel between Albany and New York with relative ease. In the Fall of 1908, the Day Line Steamboat New York was destroyed by fire at the Newburgh shipyard. The Robert Fulton was built in a hurry as a replacement in order to take part in the Hudson-Fulton celebration

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Fresh Roasted Coffee--Howard & Co., Newburgh, N.Y.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: G. E. Howard
oai_dc:dc.dc:description:
This photograph depicts some of the wares of wholesale grocer Howard & Company. Items photographed include coffee tins with the inscription "Howard & Co., Importers and Roasters, Newburgh, N.Y.", and under that "Fresh Roasted Coffee," a burlap sack of coffee with the inscription "Plantation Coffee" and a calendar opened to January 1909.

George E. Howard was a well respected businessman and amateur photographer in Newburgh, N.Y. Mr. Howard was born in Newburgh and resided at 216 Montgomery Street. At the age of 16 he was a bookkeeper in the wholesale establishment of E. T. Skidmore & Co. on Front Street. Later, he formed a partnership with Samuel J. Hilton as wholesale grocers specializing in teas and cigars. By 1909 when this photograph was taken, Howard had struck out on his own and established G. E. Howard & Co., located on Front and Second Streets. The company's product line expanded into importing coffee and other products. THe company grew steadily and with the advent of the automobile the territory covered by the firm expanded and serviced independent grocers over a radius of 60 miles. Howard owned and operated Howard & Company into the 1940s when he sold the business to John A. Riley. The last entry for George E. Howard in the Newburgh City Directory was in the 1948-1949 edition. The George Howard Co. moved to MacArthur Avenue, New Windsor, N.Y. in 1965. Howard died at age 75 on April 7, 1949.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: City Club Next to Palatine Hotel, Newburgh, NY
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: G. E. Howard
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This is a photograph of the City Club, 120 Grand Street, Newburgh, NY, around the turn of the century. The house was originally built circa 1852 by Andrew Jackson Downing and Calvert Vaux as a home for Dr. William Culbert, a physician who had married Harrietta Powell, granddaughter of Thomas Powell. Note the windows of the Palatine Hotel to the left and all the structures on Second Street to the right. The Palatine Hotel and the Second Street structures were all razed during the urban renewal of the 1970s. A fire destroyed the interior of the City Club in December 1981. The remnants of the building's shell remain, next to the Newburgh Free Library.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Newburgh Ferry Terminal Office
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: G. E. Howard
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: On May 24, 1743, Queen Anne of England granted a charter permitting a ferry to operate between Newburgh and Beacon. Ferry service was operational from that time but the Newburgh Ferry Terminal was not built until 1899. It was located at the tip of Water Street. The structure was razed in the 1970s during urban renewal.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Topographic Map - Mrs. Armstrong
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Blunt, Edmund, 1799-1866
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This map depicts a double boathouse and path leading away from the shore of the Hudson River and through a wall on a small hillside labeled Bald Hill. Below the boathouse and path is a long wharf adjacent to a small brickyard. The title Mrs. Armstrong could indicate this as the Danskammer Point area on the west shore in northern Orange County.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Topographic Map - Buttermilk Falls
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Blunt, Edmund, 1799-1866
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This map depicts two wharves on the shore of the Hudson River. One wharf is near a building labeled "shop." The house belonging to Benny Havens is located by the road in front of the second wharf A road running by the house is labeled "Road to Buttermilk." A notation reads " Near Haven's House, 1 1/2 miles below West Point." Buttermilk Falls is the original name of Highland Falls, NY., which borders the West Point Military Academy. The Dutch called this area Buttermilk Falls after the waterfall which descends into the Hudson River at this point.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Day Line Passing the Ferry Slip at Newburgh Landing During the Hudson Fulton Celebration
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Howard, G. E.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: As the speed of the early Hudson River Steamboats increased, it became possible for passengers to travel to New York and Albany during the day or overnight. This photograph gives a sense of the boat's speed as it churned by the Newburgh ferry slip.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Unidentified Sloop During the Hudson-Fulton Celebration
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Howard, G. E.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This is a photograph of an unidentified sloop during the Hudson-Fulton Celebration in Newburgh, NY, in 1909. In its simplest form, the sloop had one mast, carrying a mainsail, jib and a topsail. The sloop is credited with the development of commerce on the Hudson River during the 19th century.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Memo to the Board of Education from Newburgh Free Library Committee
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This memo reviews W. R. Eastman's recommendations for additional space for the library as well as a new arrangement of library books by subject area. It ends with a resolution to purchase No. 98 Grand Street, property of Emeline Bradley for added library space. A total of $20,000 is requested of the City of Newburgh for the Bradley building and property and alterations to more effectively house the library's book collection.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Chairman of Newburgh Free Library Committee
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This is a letter to Hiram Lozier, Chairman of the Library Committee from W. R. Eastman, Chief of the Library Division of the Department of Education, regarding the need to have the library books classified and arranged by subject. Mr. Eastman's investigation determined that there is little space for arrangement by subject and recommends that additional shelves be added. However, he states that this would be a temporary solution, and further recommends that the library consider an addition to the side of the building, one that would separate younger and older readers for the purposes of easing traffic and providing more quiet for readers. He states that the overcrowded condition is largely due to the library serving as a United States Government Depository, these items making up approxmately 1/3 of the collection. He recommends that these be placed in a separate building or storage area. He further recommends that the library hire an additional cataloger for the rearrangement and cataloging project.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Estabrook, Frank E. (1860 - 1918)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This "announcement" page describes the contents of a 42-page book of photographs and illustrations compiled by local architect Frank E. Estabrook of Newburgh, NY. The text describes the book as a "souvenir" that "contains a few of the residences, banks, public building, etc." designed by Estabrook and may be "of interest and value to parties who propose to build." Included is an advertisement for A. C. Austin Engraving Co. (80-82 State St., Albany, NY) that created all the illustrations for the book. W.H. Mapes of 64 Water St., Newburgh, NY is listed as the photographer.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Thomas Shaw's Sons
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Estabrook, Frank E. (1860 - 1918)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This image is a "card" or advertisement for Thomas Shaw's Sons who operated the Newburgh Moulding and Planing Mill, located on the corner of South William and Johnes Street, near Washington's Headquarters in Newburgh, NY. Thomas Shaw's Sons offered the services of steamboat joiners, architects and builders and assisted Frank Estabrook on his building projects. An ink drawing on the card shows the mill with its billowing smokestack and an American flag on top of the main building. The Hudson River can be seen in the distance. The text of the advertisement notes that all work is "kiln dried" and a "long distance telephone" is available.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: City Hall, Newburgh, NY
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Estabrook, Frank E. (1860 - 1918)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This page contains photographs of both interior and exterior views of City Hall, located at 83 Broadway, Newburgh, NY. In the exterior view, awnings cover several windows on the east side, the words "City Hall" are carved at the top of the building and the American flag is flying from the rooftop. Several people are standing in front of the main entrance. The interior photograph shows the Common Council Chamber with floor to ceiling windows that are covered with blinds, plus numerous chairs and a desk surrounded by a wooden railing.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Estabrook, Frank E. (1860 - 1918)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This image depicts a "card" or advertisement for A. C. Smith & Co., noted for its "modern plumbing." Featured is a "Furman" boiler that was used for steam and hot water heating. The name of the manufacturer is inscribed on the side of the engraved illustration: Herendeen Mfg. of Geneva, NY. Several public buildings and residences are listed "that we heat by this popular boiler, where they will speak for themselves."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Residences of Miss Lillie O. Estabrook and Frank E. Estabrook
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Estabrook, Frank E. (1860 - 1918)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This photograph depicts the residences of Miss Lillie O. Estabrook and Frank Estabrook, located at 202 and 204 Montgomery Street in Newburgh, NY. An older woman is seated on the porch with a younger woman standing by her side and holding a small child; seated on the lawn is a man with a older child on his lap. The man may be Frank Estabrook holding his son, Harry, and the younger woman may be his wife, Miss Waring, holding her daughter, Marguerita. The other half of the house was the residence of Lillie Estabrook, Frank's sister, who was the city librarian for many years. The house was designed by Frank E. Estabrook.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Interior of Lillie O. Estabrook's Residence
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Estabrook, Frank E. (1860 - 1918)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This photograph shows the interior of Lillie O. Estabrook's home, located at 204 Montgomery St., Newburgh, NY. The photo shows an entrance from a hallway containing a set of stairs and a pair of antlers on the wall. A sword chair is located to the left with a family portrait on the wall above it. A wooden framework with bookcases, columns and a decorative grill at the top creates an entrance to another room, perhaps a parlor. The room in the background contains a piano, two upholstered chairs and a table with an oil lamp. The house was designed by Frank E. Estabrook.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Sketches cover
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Estabrook, Frank E. (1860 - 1918)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This is believed to be the original cover of a 42-page book of photographs and illustrations complied by Newburgh(NY) architect Frank E. Estabrook to showcase the various hotels, churches and residences that he designed. Included are "cards" or advertisements from local artisans and tradesmen who worked with Estabrook. The cover contains the text "Sketches Frank E. Estabrook Newburgh, NY" plus an interior design drawing of a foyer with a diamond shaped in a window, paneled wall, upholstered bench and an umbrella stand. The type is set off by an engraved flourish design. In the lower right-hand corner are the words "A. C. Austrin Engraving Co. Albany, NY".
